sen.j: 山城国 （やましろのくに） は、かつて日本の地方行政区分だった令制国の一つで、畿内に位置する。
sen.e: Yamashiro no Kuni was one of the administrative province (Ryoseikoku) and located in Kinai.
sen.cmt: 令制国→administrative province (Ryoseikoku) としました。
sen.e: Yamashiro no Kuni, located in Kinai, was one of the administrative province (Ryoseikoku).
Yamashiro no Kuni, located in Kinai, was one of the administrative province (Ryoseikoku).

sen.j: 現在の京都府南部にあたる。
sen.e: It was situated in the actual southern part of Kyoto.
It was situated in the southern part of present day Kyoto.
It was situated in the southern part of present day Kyoto.

sen.j: 別称は城州（まれに山州とも）、雍州。
sen.e: It was also called Joshu (unusually it is also alled Sanshu) or Yoshu.
It was also called Joshu (unusually it is also alled Sanshu) or Yoshu.
It was also called Joshu (unusually it is also alled Sanshu) or Yoshu.

sen.j: 延喜式での格は国司国等級区分。
sen.e: In the Engi-Shiki, it is ranked as Kokushi-kuni tokyu (a Kokushi (official) governing province).
sen.cmt: 国司国等級→Kokushi-kuni tokyu (a Kokushi (official) governing province)としました。
sen.e: In the Engi-Shiki, it is ranked as Kokushi-kuni tokyu (a Kokushi (official) governing province).
In the Engishiki, it is ranked as Kokushi-kuni tokyu (a Kokushi (official) governing province).

sen.j: 「やましろ」は、古くは山代と書き、7世紀に山背国という表記で国が建てられた。
sen.e: "Yamashiro" is written as 山代 in ancient times, and in the 7th century, the province (kuni) was founded with the name written as 山背国.
"Yamashiro" was written as 山代 in ancient times, and in the 7th century, the province (kuni) was founded with the name written as 山背国.
sen.cmt: 現在形から過去形に変更
sen.e: "Yamashiro" was written as 山代 in ancient times, and in the 7th century, the province (kuni) was founded with the name written as 山背国.

sen.j: 延暦13年（794年）11月8日の平安京命名の際に、桓武天皇が、山河が襟帯して自然に城をなす形勝から、山城国に改称した。
sen.e: On November 8, 794 (Enryaku 13), when the capital was named Heian-kyo (Heian Palace), the Emperor Kammu changed the second letter of province's name to 山城国
On November 8, 794 (Enryaku 13), when the capital was named Heian-kyo (Heian Palace), the Emperor Kammu changed the second letter of the province's name to 山城国
On November 8, 794 (Enryaku 13), when the capital was named Heian-kyo (Heian Palace), the Emperor Kammu changed the second letter of the province's name to 山城国

sen.j: 平城京時代の木簡を見る限り、山代国、山背国と表記は並存しているようである。
sen.e: As far as we can guess from the writing of "mokkan"－slip of wood used for writing at the Heijo-kyo (Heijo Palace) period－, in writing the name of Yamashiro no Kuni, 山代国 and 山背国 seem to have coexisted with 山城国.
Based on the writings of "mokkan"－strips of wood used for writing during the Heijo-kyo (Heijo Palace) period－, the notations of Yamashiro no Kuni as 山代国 and 山背国 seem to have coexisted with 山城国.
Based on the writings of "mokkan"－strips of wood used for writing during the Heijo-kyo (Heijo Palace) period, the notations of Yamashiro no Kuni as 山代国 and 山背国 seem to have coexisted with 山城国.

sen.j: 国府は、和名類聚抄に、河陽離宮。
sen.e: According to Wamyo Ruijusho, the provincial government office (Kokufu) was situated at the Kaya Imperial Villa (Kaya Detached Palace).
According to Wamyo Ruijusho, the provincial government office (Kokufu) was situated at the Kaya Imperial Villa (Kaya Detached Palace).
According to Wamyo Ruijusho, the provincial government office (Kokufu) was situated at the Kaya Imperial Villa (Kaya Detached Palace).

sen.j: 拾芥抄では、乙訓郡、府と記載されている。
sen.e: On the other hand, in Shugaisho, there is a following description, "Otokuni-gun (Otokuni District), Fu (Office)."
On the other hand, it is recorded as "Otokuni-gun (Otokuni District), Fu (Office)" in Shugaisho.
sen.cmt: description は記載より具体的に説明するという意味があるので、もう少し簡素に意味になるように recorded を使いました。
sen.e: On the other hand, it is recorded as "Otokuni-gun (Otokuni District), Fu (Office)" in Shugaisho.

sen.j: 節用集（易林訂正）；奥書 跋末「慶長ニ易林誌」に、乙訓郡、府と記載されている。
sen.e: In Setsuyoshu (proofed by Ekirin), in the matters of colophon and afterword titled "Keicho-two Enirinshi," there is a description of "Otokuni-gun (Otokuni District), Fu (Office)."
sen.cmt: 奥書 跋末→colophon and afterwordとしました。
sen.e: In the colophon and afterword titled "Keicho-two Enirinshi" of Setsuyoshu (proofed by Ekirin) it is also recorded as "Otokuni-gun (Otokuni District), Fu (Office)."
sen.cmt: description は記載より具体的に説明するという意味があるので、もう少し簡素に意味になるように recorded を使いました。
sen.e: In the colophon and afterward titled "Keicho-two Enirinshi" of Setsuyoshu (proofed by Ekirin) it is also recorded as "Otokuni-gun (Otokuni District), Fu (Office)."

sen.j: 守護所は、当初、山城国守護を京都守護が兼任していたため、京都守護の御家人の館が当てられた。
sen.e: As for Shugosho (governor's office), at first, the mansion of the Gokenin of Kyoto shugo (Kyoto governor) was designated because the person who hold the post of Kyoto Shugo concurrently took charge of Yamashiro Province's Shugo.

As for Shugosho (governor's office), at first, the mansion of the Gokenin of Kyoto Shugo (Kyoto governor) was designated because the person holding the post of Kyoto Shugo concurrently took charge of Yamashiro Province's Shugo.

As for Shugosho (governor's office), at first, the mansion of the Gokenin of Kyoto Shugo (Kyoto governor) was designated because the person holding the post of Kyoto Shugo concurrently took charge of Yamashiro Province's Shugo.

sen.j: その後、六波羅探題が兼務するようになり、守護所も六波羅となった。
sen.e: Later, Rokuhara Tandai became to hold the post of the Province Shugo, and therfore, the office (Shugosho) was moved to Rokuhara.
Later, Rokuhara Tandai held the post of the Province Shugo, and therfore, the office (Shugosho) was moved to Rokuhara.
Later, Rokuhara Tandai held the post of the Province Shugo, and therefore, the office (Shugosho) was moved to Rokuhara.

sen.j: 室町時代に山城国を宇治川を境に上三郡と下五郡に分割して、それぞれに守護代を任ずるようになってからは、上三郡の守護所が宇治槙島に置かれ、下五郡の守護所が淀など数ヶ所に置かれた。
sen.e: In Muromachi period, the Yamashiro Province was divided into two parts along the Uji River－three upper districts and five lower districts-, and to each of the district an associate shugo (shugodai) was designated. Since then, Shugosho in charge of the three upper districts was situated in Uji Makishima, while to cover the five lower distracts, Shugosho was placed in several places such as Yodo.

In Muromachi period, the Yamashiro Province was divided along the Uji River into three upper districts and five lower districts; after an associate shugo (shugodai) was designated to each district the Shugosho in charge of the three upper districts was situated in Uji Makishima, while Shugosho for the five lower districts were placed in several places such as Yodo.

In Muromachi period, the Yamashiro Province was divided along the Uji River into three upper districts and five lower districts; after an associate shugo (shugodai) was designated to each district the Shugosho in charge of the three upper districts was situated in Uji Makishima, while Shugosho for the five lower districts were placed in several places such as Yodo.
Ichinomiya (primary shrine), Provincial monastery (temple), and Others
Ichinomiya (primary shrine), Provincial monastery (temple), and Others
Ichinomiya (primary shrine), Provincial monastery (temple), and Others

sen.j: 国分寺は、僧寺と尼寺ともに相楽郡にあった。
sen.e: The provincial temple －with monastery for priests as well as convent for priestess－, were located in Soraku District.
The provincial temple －with monastery for priests as well as convent for priestess－, were located in Soraku District.
The provincial temple －with monastery for priests as well as convent for priestess－, were located in Soraku District.

sen.j: 恭仁宮大極殿が746年に僧寺とされた。
sen.e: The Daigokuden Hall of the Kuni no Miya Shrine was designated as a monastery (soji) in 746.
sen.cmt: 恭仁宮大極殿→The Daigokuden Hall of the Kuni no Miya Shrine としました。
sen.e: The Daigokuden Hall of the Kuni no Miya Shrine was designated as a monastery (soji) in 746.
The Daigokuden Hall of the Kuni no Miya Shrine was designated as a monastery (soji) in 746.

sen.j: その後再建されるが衰退する。
sen.e: After that it was reconstructed but its influence was declined.
Afterwards it was reconstructed but its influence declined.
Afterwards it was reconstructed but its influence declined.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代には平等院の末寺となっていたようである。
sen.e: In Kamakura period, it seems that the temple was categolized as the lowest level temple within the Byodo-in school
In Kamakura period, it seems that the temple was categolized as the lowest level temple within the Byodo-in school
In Kamakura period, it seems that the temple was categorized as the lowest level temple within the Byodo-in school

sen.j: 場所は現在の木津川市加茂町にあたる。
sen.e: The provincial temple was located at Kamo-cho, Kizugawa city.
The provincial temple was located at present day Kamo-cho, Kizugawa city.
The provincial temple was located at present day Kamo-cho, Kizugawa city.

sen.j: 1925年（大正14年）に国分寺のそばで大量の古瓦が発掘され、尼寺の跡だと考えられている。
sen.e: In 1925 (Taisho 14) a large number of old tiles were found near the provincial temple, and that makes consider that there was a convent there.
In 1925 (14th year of Taisho) a large number of old [roof] tiles were excavated near the provincial temple, and implying that there was a convent there.
In 1925 (14th year of Taisho) a large number of old [roof] tiles were excavated near the provincial temple, and implying that there was a convent there.

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳には、大社53座37社（うち名神大社23座16社）・小社69座59社の計122座96社が記載されており、他に宮中の36座（大30座・小6座）、京中の大3座が記載されている。
sen.e: In Engi-Shiki Jinmei-cho (shrines' name directory), 122-za and 96-sha are recorded, including 53-za/37-sha of taisha (big shrinses)－within these shrines, 23-za/16-sha of dai myojin are included－, and 69-za/59-sha of shosha (small shrines). In addition to these shrines, 36-za (30 big za, and 6 small za) in the imperial court and 3-daiza in Kyoto are also registered.

In Engi-Shiki Jinmei-cho (shrines' name directory) a total of 122-za and 96-sha are recorded, consisting of 53-za/37-sha of taisha (big shrinses)(within these shrines, 23-za/16-sha of dai myojin are included) and 69-za/59-sha of shosha (small shrines). In addition to these shrines, 36-za (30 big za, and 6 small za) in the imperial court and 3-daiza in Kyoto are also registered.

In Engi-Shiki Jinmei-cho (shrines' name directory) a total of 122-za and 96-sha are recorded, consisting of 53-za/37-sha of taisha (big shrines)(within these shrines, 23-za/16-sha of dai myojin are included) and 69-za/59-sha of shosha (small shrines). In addition to these shrines, 36-za (30 big za, and 6 small za) in the imperial court and 3-daiza in Kyoto are also registered.

sen.j: 一宮は京都市の賀茂神社（北区 (京都市)の賀茂別雷神社（上賀茂神社）及び左京区の賀茂御祖神社（下鴨神社））である。
sen.e: Kamo Shrines are the first shrines (Ichinomiya) in Kyoto －Kamowakeikazuchi Shrine (called Kamigamo Shrine) at Kita district, and Kamomioya Shrine (called Shimogamo Shrine) at Sakyo district.
Kamo Shrines are the first shrines (Ichinomiya) in Kyoto －Kamowakeikazuchi Shrine (called Kamigamo Shrine) at Kita district, and Kamomioya Shrine (called Shimogamo Shrine) at Sakyo district.
Kamo Shrines are the first shrines (Ichinomiya) in Kyoto －Kamowakeikazuchi Shrine (called Kamigamo Shrine) at Kita district, and Kamomioya Shrine (called Shimogamo Shrine) at Sakyo district.

sen.j: 山城国の一宮指定には、地方の諸国と異なって神祇官が関わっていると思われ、11世紀末から諸国でそれぞれに一宮が成立していく中で、畿内ではそれに対応して12世紀になってから決められたと考えられる。
sen.e: It is considered that Jingi-kan had some influence over the designation of the first shrine (Ichinomiya) in Yamashiro Province, which unlikely happened in other local provinces, and while the establishment of Ichinomiya in other provinces was took place during the 11th century, in Kinai (Kansai Region), the Ichinomiya was designated in the 12th century.

Unlike in other local provinces, it is considered that Jingi-kan had some influence over the designation of the first shrine (Ichinomiya) in Yamashiro Province; because of this, while the establishment of Ichinomiya in other provinces took place starting at the end of the 11th century the designation of Ichinomiya in Kinai (Kansai Region) began during the 12th century.
sen.cmt: 前半順序変更；後半書き直し
sen.e: Unlike in other local provinces, it is considered that Jingi-kan had some influence over the designation of the first shrine (Ichinomiya) in Yamashiro Province; because of this, while the establishment of Ichinomiya in other provinces took place starting at the end of the 11th century the designation of Ichinomiya in Kinai (Kansai Region) began during the 12th century.

sen.j: 二宮以下は存在しない。
sen.e: There is no secondary (Ninomiya) and lower level shrines.
There is no secondary (Ninomiya) and lower level shrines.
There is no secondary (Ninomiya) and lower level shrines.
As for the soja shrine, the information is not available.
As for the soja shrine, the information is not available.
As for the soja shrine, the information is not available.

sen.j: 直江兼続従五位下 （天正11年（1583年）～）
土岐定政従五位下 （文禄2年（1593年）～）
竹腰正信従五位下 （慶長16年（1611年）～）
土岐頼行従五位下 （寛永元年（1624年）10月28日～）
